40 Women SHGs were formed in two clusters in Gangilihat block and federated in two self reliance cooperatives. With the aim of improving livelihood options Dairy, Goatery and vegetable cultivation were taken as income generating enterprizes and the SHGs were motivated to adopt them. Fodder Plot development, construction of polyhouse, rain water harvesting tank and compost units alongwith promotion of improve breed of cattle, buffalo anf goats were the key activities of the project.

94 Women SHGs of 36 villages were formed and federated in three self reliance cooperatives viz., Talla Johar SRC, Nachani, Laxmibai SRC, Berinag and Gaura Devi SRC, Gangolihat. These Women SHGs are collecting small saving and inter-loaning among themselves for production activities. The SHG member were trained to carry out official activities of the SHGs and SRC as well alongwith imparting knowledge of law through conduct of Law literacy Camp and Mahila Sammelans.
Farmers were motivated to keep improved breed of goats and adopt goatry as income generation enterprize for socio-economc upliftment of weaker section.

Fodder Plots were developed in Munshyari and Berinag blocks and Fodder grasses and multipurpose trees were planted in order to get year round green fodder. Farmers were motivated to adopt dairy as income generation enterprize for socio-economic upliftment. Assistance was also received from MNREGA in this endeavour.

Fodder Plots were developed in 57 ha area in Bankot cluster and 4920 multipurpose trees and grasses were planted in order to get year round green fodder. 33 water retaining ponds and 10 Fodder grass nursery were also developed.
Maintenance of drinking water supply schemes were undertaken and motivational programme on saving and judicious use of drinking water was organised for villagers

Farmers’ Producer Groups were formed in 18 revenue villages of Birthi and Pawadhar clusters and all were registered under the cooperative act. In order to maintain direct communication to farmers, 33 SHGs were formed in which 459 women member had been associated.

The project aims to promote decentralized renewable energy (DRE) among rural mountain communities to enhance livelihood activities. The renewable energy hinged technologies is being incubated to catalyse the livelihood finance, skilling, social entrepreneurships and value chain-based marketing in the mountain specificities. title: INDIAN ASSOCIATION OF SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATIONISTS
detailsOfAchievement: The Indian Association of Soil and Water Conservationists (IASWC) was established in 1972 at Dehradun, as a non-profit making body to encourage wise land use planning and conservation of soil and water resources so that these basic resources can be utilized to sustain mankind. The IASWC resorts itself through its members to serve as a forum of scientists, conservation professionals, administrators and policy makers in assessing the need for soil and water conservation and watershed management. Aims and Objectives â€¢ To promote and disseminate the knowledge, practice and research in the science and technology of Soil and Water Conservation. â€¢ To encourage free exchange of ideas amongst those contributing to the advancement of Soil and Water Conservation such as Agronomists, Agrostologists, Ecologists, Engineers, Foresters, Geologists, Land Users and Soil Scientists etc. by organizing symposia, lectures and bringing out literature etc. Activities of the Association Publication of Indian Journal of Soil Conservation: During the last four decades, the Indian Journal of Soil Conservation (IJSC) made its journey starting in humble beginning during 1973 as a Soil Conservation Digest (Vol.1 (1973) to Vol. 5 (1977). It was renamed as Indian Journal of Soil Conservation w.e.f. Vol.6 (1978). IASWC Awards and Honours The IASWC has instituted the following awards and honours from 2004 onwards for outstanding contributions in the field of Natural Resource Management: Honorary Fellows; Fellows ; Young Soil Conservationist Award ; IASWC Gold Medal ; Best Research Paper Award ; Dr K.G. Tejwani Award Conferences organized by IASWC The IASWC, besides publishing the Journal, also holds national and regional conferences. Since 2005, the IASWC has organized the following International, National and Regional Conferences: 1. National Seminar on â€œSoil Conservation and Watershed Managementâ€ at New Delhi September 17-18, 1985. 2. National Seminar on â€œLand and Water management in Ravinesâ€ at Dehradun February 11-13, 1987. 3. 8th International Soil Conservation Organization (ISCO) Conference on â€œSoil and Water Conservation- Challenges and Opportunitiesâ€ at New Delhi December 4-8, 1994. 4. National Conference on â€œResource Conservation and Watershed Managementâ€ (RCWM-2001) at Dehradun May 23-25, 2001. 5. National Conference on â€œResource Conserving Technologies for Social Upliftmentâ€ (RCTSU) held at NASC, New Delhi from December 7-9, 2004. 6. National Conference on â€œNatural Resource Management for Eco-development and Livelihood Securityâ€ (NEMRLSI) held at CSWCRTI, Research Centre, Udhagamandalam (Tamil Nadu) from November, 24-25, 2005. 7. Conference on â€œNatural Resource Management for Social Developmentâ€ (NRMSD) held at Pune, Maharashtra from October 11-13, 2006. 8. Conference on â€œEnvironment and Livelihood Security through Resource Management (ELSRM)â€ in Northern India held at CSWCRTI, Research Centre, Chandigarh from October 29-31, 2007. 9. Conference on â€œFood and Environment Security through Resource Conservation (FESCO)â€ in Central India: Challenges and Opportunities held at CSWCRTI, Research Centre, Agra from September, 16-18, 2009. 10. Joint Indo-Canadian workshop on â€œAdaptive and Sustainable Solutions for Water Integrity, Safety, Security and Supplyâ€ at CSWCRTI, Research Centre, Chandigarh (India) during January 7-8, 2011. 11. Conference on â€œLivelihood and Environmental Security through Resource Conservation in Eastern Region of India (LESRC-2012)â€ at Bhubaneswar (Odisha) April 5-7, 2012.

title: INDIAN SOCIETY OF REMOTE SENSING
detailsOfAchievement: Indian Society of Remote Sensing (ISRS) was established in 1969 under the Societies Registration Act XXI of 1860 with the main objective to help towards advancement, dissemination and application of the knowledge of Remote Sensing technology, which is deemed to include photo interpretation, photogrammetry, image processing, and other related technologies in the field of survey, planning and management of natural resources and other areas of application by organising seminars/symposium and by publishing journal, bulletins, proceedings, etc. It also provides recognition for outstanding contribution in the field of Remote Sensing by way of Awards, Medals and other suitable methods. ISRS registered office is located at IIRS campus, Dehra Dun and presently also has 24 Chapters in different States. Starting with 56 members, the Society has now grown into a premier professional body with membership of around 4700 members, including both individual and Institutional members. ISRS also has a status of an ordinary membership (Category 6) of the International Society of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing (ISPRS) and has supported ISPRS in its objectives of promoting international co-operation, co-ordination and advancement of Geo-spatial technology and related sciences to improve quality of mankind by sustainable natural resources development and environmental management by participating/conducting workshops symposia of different working Groups. ISRS is also ordinary member of Asian Association of Remote Sensing (AARS), which is an Asian non-government organisation dedicated to promote remote sensing through exchange of information, mutual cooperation and international understanding and goodwill amongst the member countries of Asia-Pacific Region. ISRS brings out its journal with the name of "Journal of the Indian Society of Remote Sensing (JISRS) bi-monthly from February, 2016. Now, its Volume 44, Issue 4, August, 2016 has been published. The JISRS has become truly international by virtue of its joint publication with international reputed technical journal publisher â€œSpringerâ€.

title: Indian Water Resources Society
detailsOfAchievement: IWRS is a professional body dedicated to work for advancement and development of water resources in the India. It publishers a quarterly issue of technical journal named as â€œJournal of Indian Water Resources Societyâ€ It is circulated to all its members (7650 members from all over the country). It organizes national and International conferences, seminar, workshop etc. from time to time on specific topics for discussion and dissemination of updated knowledge and technology in the field for water resources development and management, Other activities of the society are to undertake research, planning, development, education and training in the field of conservation and management of natural resources namely water- (i) The advancement of research, planning, development, management, education and training as well as establishment of a common meeting group for physical, biological and social scientists, engineers and other persons concerned with water resources. (ii) To undertake research, planning, development, education and training in the field of conversation and management of natural resources namely water. (iii) To undertake research, planning, development, education and training for optimal use of water for rural development. (iv) To provide a focal point for the collection, organization and dissemination of ideas and information relating to the broad spectrum of water problems. (v) To provide necessary forum for communication in water resources science and technology through its meetings and publication.

detailsOfAchievement: SBMA is Committed to a human development approach, SBMA facilitates empowerment of children and women by developing their own capabilities and strengthening their institutions. The underlying principles of SBMA in all its programs are Nurturing community based groups, Developing their capacities for addressing the developmental issues and managing them, Enabling access to services provided by state and private agencies, Creating services where others are not forthcoming, Aggregating community based groups and facilitating them to emerge as community based organization for continuing the interventions initiated by SBMA. SBMA focuses its intervention on Education, Health, Community Governance, Livelihood Promotion, Natural Resource Management & Child Right & Child Protection. In each of the thematic areas SBMA is involved in Capacity building, Advocacy and Networking, Field Implementation & Based Organizations. All programs are catalyzing holistic development of the communities through interventions in Education, livelihood, Health,Water & Sanitation, Disaster Management, Child & Mother Health etc. 40800 in Chmoli and Uttarkashi children derived benefit from de worming campaigning, 14601 persons treated for various ailments through Multi Specialty Health Camps, 1341 pregnant women have received tetanus toxide vaccinations, 592 mothers received Ante Natal Care and Pre Natal Care26 disabled children were recommended for certification,Total 4232 boys and girls in 180 villages examined for nutritional deficiency, 2500 children covered for Hepatitis B vaccine,Approx 500 patients examined and counseled through four specialized camps of RTI&STI.
